 Summary: 
 
 At Yang's hearing before a panel of the Refugee Division, his possible exclusion under article 1F(a) of the Convention (crimes against humanity) was raised as an issue for the first time. Yang's counsel sought an adjournment to prepare for argument on this issue. The panel adjourned for 80 minutes to consider the adjournment request, during which time counsel was allowed to use the Division's document centre. The panel refused the adjournment request, and the hearing was completed. Yang applied for judicial review.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, allowed the application and referred the matter for redetermination.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

 Lisa Sturgess and Rod Holloway, for the applicant; 
 
 Helen Park, for the respondent.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

 Legal Services Society, Vancouver, British Columbia, for the applicant; 
 
 Morris Rosenberg, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 This application was heard on March 15, 2001, in Vancouver, British Columbia, by Lutfy, A.C.J., of the Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, who delivered the following decision on March 22, 2001.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>   <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>     <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[1] 
   
 Lutfy, Associate Chief Justice 
 : It was only during the applicant's testimony that the Refugee Division panel first raised the issue of exclusion under Article 1F(a) of the  
 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees 
  as a matter relevant to the determination of his refugee claim. None of the communications between the refugee claim officer and the applicant's counsel prior to the hearing had indicated this possibility.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[2] 
  The panel recessed to allow counsel to advise the applicant that Article 1F(a) was in issue.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[3] 
  After this short break, counsel for the applicant sought an adjournment to complete the hearing on another day.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[4] 
  In response, the panel recessed for a second time to consider the request for an adjournment. In the meantime, arrangements were made to allow counsel to use the Refugee Division's document centre.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[5] 
  The hearing reconvened some eighty minutes later when counsel renewed his request for an adjournment to another day. This request was refused. The panel noted that counsel was "imputed to know the law and imputed and deemed also to recognize sets of facts for what they are".  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[6] 
  Counsel was told that he could object to the ruling and seek relief elsewhere if he thought that the refusal of the adjournment was inappropriate. Counsel was reminded that he should not be "in contempt of the process" and the hearing continued.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[7] 
  Section 69.1(5) of the  
 Immigration Act 
 , R.S.C. 1985, c. I-2, provides that the Refugee Division shall give the claimant a reasonable opportunity to present evidence, question witnesses and make representations.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[8] 
  Section 69(6) of the  
 Act 
  requires that the Refugee Division will only grant an adjournment when it is satisfied that the proceeding will not be unreasonably impeded.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[9] 
  Section 13(4) of the  
 Convention Refugee Determination Division Rules 
 , SOR/93-45, lists a number of criteria to be considered by the Refugee Division in determining whether an adjournment of a hearing would unreasonably impede the proceeding. These include the nature and complexity of the issues, the nature of the evidence to be presented, counsel's knowledge of and experience with similar proceedings and the effort made by the parties to seek the adjournment at the earliest opportunity. These criteria are consistent with those suggested by the Court of Appeal in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  Imm. L.R.(2d) 239 (F.C.A.).  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[10] 
  While the circumstances differ from case to case, the Federal Court has consistently emphasized the importance of adequate notice to the refugee claimant concerning the possibility of the exclusion issue:  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.).  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[11] 
  In my view, when the exclusion issue is raised for the first time during a hearing, the panel will want to grant the refugee claimant an adjournment for a meaningful period of time. The eighty-minute adjournment afforded the applicant in this case was insufficient. This short mid-afternoon adjournment was inadequate notice to protect the applicant's rights under s. 69.1(5). The applicant and his counsel had a right to a longer adjournment to consider and prepare for the exclusion issue. The panel in this proceeding should have granted an adjournment to another day. Its failure to do so constitutes a breach of procedural fairness and natural justice.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[12] 
  Accordingly, this application for judicial review will be granted and the matter referred for rehearing and redetermination before a differently constituted panel. In view of this outcome, the parties agreed that it would be unnecessary to consider the substantive issues concerning the decision to exclude the applicant under Article 1F(a). Neither party suggested the certification of a serious question.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Application allowed.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Editor: Geoffrey D. Peters/slm  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 [End of document]

statutes: Immigration Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. I-2, sect. 69.1(5)
Immigration Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. I-2, sect. 69(6)
Convention Refugee Determination Division Rules, SOR/93-45, sect. 13(4)
legal_issues: The procedural requirements for raising new grounds for exclusion during an administrative hearing.
The adequacy of time provided to respond to newly raised issues in an administrative hearing.
The standard of procedural fairness required when an administrative tribunal raises a new issue during a hearing.
The scope of an administrative tribunal's discretion to grant or deny an adjournment request.
The relationship between statutory rights to present evidence and the denial of an adjournment.
The criteria for determining whether an adjournment would unreasonably impede administrative proceedings.
factual_background: A refugee claim hearing was held before a Refugee Division panel.
During the hearing, the panel raised the issue of exclusion under Article 1F(a) of the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees for the first time.
The claimant's counsel requested an adjournment to prepare for argument on the newly raised exclusion issue.
The panel adjourned for 80 minutes to consider the adjournment request, allowing counsel access to the Division's document centre.
The panel subsequently denied the request for an adjournment and the hearing continued.
The claimant applied for judicial review of the panel's decision.
The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, allowed the application and ordered the matter to be redetermined.
Prior to the hearing, communications between the refugee claim officer and the claimant's counsel did not indicate the possibility of the exclusion issue being raised.

Applicants: The Refugee Division raised the issue of exclusion under Article 1F(a) of the Convention for the first time during the applicant's testimony.
The panel refused a request for an adjournment to prepare for argument on the newly raised exclusion issue.
The 80-minute adjournment granted was insufficient to adequately prepare for the exclusion issue.

The refusal of a longer adjournment breached procedural fairness and natural justice, violating section 69.1(5) of the Immigration Act which guarantees a reasonable opportunity to present evidence and make representations.
The applicant and counsel were entitled to a longer adjournment to consider and prepare for the exclusion issue.
Respondents: Counsel was imputed to know the law and recognize relevant facts.
Counsel could object to the ruling and seek relief elsewhere.
An adjournment would only be granted if the proceeding would not be unreasonably impeded (citing section 69(6) of the Immigration Act).

The Refugee Division considered criteria outlined in Section 13(4) of the Convention Refugee Determination Division Rules when considering the adjournment request (nature of issues, evidence, counsel's experience, timing of request).

court_analysis: The Refugee Division panel raised the issue of exclusion under Article 1F(a) of the Refugee Convention for the first time during the applicant’s hearing, despite no prior indication of this possibility in pre-hearing communications.

The court found that the 80-minute adjournment granted to counsel to prepare for this newly raised issue was insufficient to protect the applicant’s rights to procedural fairness and natural justice, specifically the right to a reasonable opportunity to present evidence and make representations as outlined in section 69.1(5) of the Immigration Act.

The court acknowledged section 69(6) of the Immigration Act and section 13(4) of the Convention Refugee Determination Division Rules, which address adjournments and criteria for determining if a proceeding would be unreasonably impeded, but determined these were not adequately applied in this case.

The court relied on established precedent emphasizing the importance of adequate notice regarding potential exclusion issues, finding that a 'meaningful' adjournment is required when such an issue is raised for the first time during a hearing.

The court reasoned that the panel’s expectation that counsel should 'know the law' did not negate the applicant’s right to a reasonable opportunity to prepare a response to a new legal argument being applied to their case.
The court concluded that the panel’s refusal of a longer adjournment constituted a breach of procedural fairness and natural justice, necessitating a rehearing before a different panel.
final_outcome: Application for judicial review was allowed.
Matter referred for rehearing and redetermination before a differently constituted panel.
